article_title: Measuring Mitochondrial Apoptotic Priming by BH3 Profiling Predicts Induction Outcome for Acute Myeloid Leukemia Patients

abstract_text: Abstract 239 The mechanistic basis for differential response to induction therapy in AML is poorly understood. Our laboratory has found that primary normal and malignant cells vary greatly in the proximity of their mitochondria to the threshold of apoptosis. This sensitivity is largely dictated by the BCL-2 family of proteins at the mitochondria. Cells that have greater sensitivity to apoptosis are referred to as being more “primed” for death. Using a novel FACS-based assay called BH3 profiling, we can directly measure the degree of priming for individual cells within heterogeneous samples obtained from patients. BH3 profiling measures mitochondrial response to a panel of peptides composed of the BH3 domains of death-signaling proteins in the BCL-2 family. We studied the mitochondria of myeloblasts of more than 50 patients prior to their receiving induction or re-induction chemotherapy for AML. Gating for the AML blast population using CD45 and side scatter, we have found that patients with highly primed blasts are significantly more likely to achieve a complete remission (CR) than patients with low priming. Specifically, priming was found to predict killing by topoisomerase II inhibitors like etoposide, idarubicin, daunorubicin and mitoxantrone used during induction chemotherapy. Moreover, we measured the priming of normal human hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) within the Lin − CD34 + CD38 − CD45RA − CD90 + gate. We found that HSC mitochondria have an intermediate level of priming that forms the boundary line between the priming of responsive versus refractory myeloblasts. AML blasts from refractory patients are less primed than normal HSCs and are thus predicted to even survive regimens that would kill normal HSCs. For these refractory patients, our BH3 profiling revealed that even refractory myeloblasts are much more dependent on BCL-2 than are HSCs. We show that at the cellular level, even refractory myeloblasts are much more sensitive to BCL-2 antagonist ABT-737 than are HSCs. Cumulatively, these findings show that priming is a major mechanistic determinant of patient outcome following standard induction chemotherapy. Priming measurements by BH3 profiling can therefore better help categorize patient prognosis to guide personalized therapy. Moreover, BH3 profiling opens a possible avenue for treatment, BCL-2 inhibition, for patients that are currently unresponsive to standard induction chemotherapy. Patients that achieve CR but later relapse are also more primed than refractory patients. Normal HSCs (orange) are intermediately primed and may set the therapeutic window.
